story.title: We understand - visiting the dentist can be scary
story.content: Many of us remember unpleasant experiences from childhood dental visits. That's why we've created a completely different place - a safe, comfortable space. Our unique approach is based on listening, endless patience, and understanding children's fears and concerns.

doctorSpotlight.title: A Personal Word from Dr. Lena
doctorSpotlight.message: As a mother and a dentist, I understand the concerns of parents and children. My goal is to create a positive experience for every child who walks into the clinic. I believe pediatric dentistry is much more than a medical treatment - it's an opportunity to build healthy habits for life.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Answers to the questions parents ask most often

items.q: At what age should dental treatments begin?
items.a: It's recommended to bring your child for a first visit around age two and a half, or after the first teeth emerge. An early visit helps the child get accustomed to the clinic environment and build positive experiences from the start.

items.q: What if my child doesn't cooperate?
items.a: That's perfectly fine! We adjust the pace to the child, sometimes starting with just a brief introduction and play. Our psychological approach works with most children, and they connect quickly.

items.q: Can we come just for a consultation?
items.a: Absolutely. There's no obligation to continue treatment. An initial consultation allows you and your child to meet us and feel comfortable before proceeding with treatment.

items.q: How do I prepare my child for the first visit?
items.a: Talk about the visit in a positive, light way, emphasizing that it's about meeting the doctor and counting teeth. Avoid scary terms or stories about negative experiences.

items.q: Can parents be present during treatment?
items.a: Of course! We encourage parental presence, especially with younger children. However, some older children cooperate better when they come in alone.
